note.p: Death: The house of his cousin, Mrs Wolf, Kensington, Middlesex (16 January 1715)
Education: St Paul's School; Pupil of George Bull, Rector of Suddington, Gloucestershire, and afterwards Bishop of St David's; Trinity College, Cambridge (admitted 1677)

Career: Travelled to Paris with Edmond Halley (FRS 1678) and then made the Grand Tour (1680-1682); corresponded with John Tillotson (FRS 1672); lived at Aachen and later Florence, returning to England by way of Germany and Holland (1691); had strong Jacobite sympathies and joined the Non-Jurors, returned to the Church of England (1710); took part in various charitable enterprises, including the establishment of charity schools; Commissioner for Building Fifty New Churches; first person to be buried in Lamb Conduit Fields
Sources: Bulloch's Roll; DNB; St Paul's; Hunter; Foster
References: Sir Alan Cook, 'Halley the Londoner' in NR 1993 vol 47 pp 163-177
A Cook, 'Rome and the Royal Society, 1660-1740' in NR 2004 vol 58 pp 3-19
Notes: Hunter gives different year of birth (1665) and states that he was not admitted until 30 Nov 1695.
